OK, I am no genius, so I don't follow half of what's being presented, but I am having difficulty understanding that puzzle question, and the reason is simple. When I was in school, we had to write a program in HTML/JS exactly like this. We used a 3x3 grid, using randomized numbers, 1-8. You played by clicking on the number and the code would check for a valid blank square adjacent to the chosen number and move the number to that space or just give a notice that wasn't a valid move. After each valid move, the code would check to see if the numbers were in sequence and if so, announce it.  I've played games like this a million times as a kid, so I cannot see how in the heck he's saying that there is no solution.  This reminds me of a Numberphile video where they said that the sum of all positive integers from 0 to infinity is  -1/12 and they did so because of some twisted mathematical "logic". Yet, actual logic will tell you that no amount of positive integers added together could ever equal a negative fraction.
So if the number of inversions was even, would this always be solvable?

Does long winded:  three lemmas  a corollary, and an induction argument qualify as elegant?  Half an hour condensed.  A horizontal move doesn't permute order and is thus an even permutation. Obvious.  A vertical move rotates three consecutive letters: also obvious after a little bit of thought, and is an even permutation.  No composition of even permutations yields an odd permutation.  This assumes that no odd permutation can  leave every letter fixed , a non trivial fact.  But he assumes this without proof.

Kinda late but,  The puzzle is unsolvable from his specified start sate. That is because in his start state there is only a single pair that is in wrong order.(H,G) (In his words, a single pair of "inversion"). Yet, if you watch the proof, any legal move you can make only changes the number of inverted pairs by 2,-2 or 0. As such, it's not possible to go from a state where there are odd number of inversions(1 in this case) to a state where there are even number of inversions(0 in this case)  Numberphile (I'm a fan) video is pretty much horseshit in the context of regular arithmetic. Unless you are a theoretical physicist I would not pay any attention to regularization of divergent series.

Case B is just Case A but in reverse. Case A is making a column move starting with 2 ordered pairs, and it inverts both of them. Think of Case B as undoing Case A, which is equivalent to going from 2 inverted pairs back to their original ordered state.   In general, what a column move does is simply changing the inversion of exactly 2 pairs. If they were both inverted, they become in order, and vice versa. And if there was one of each, the inverted one becomes in order and the ordered one becomes inverted, resulting in effectively no change.
There are already two inversions in D A C. (A, D) and (C, D).

If anyone is curious about, what if in a system where this (H,G) is in order rather assuming it out of order in because of alphabets. All the lemmas and corollary will still be true just the parity will change from odd to even. So in big picture if (H,G) is in order then (G,H) will be out of order and parity will change from 0 -> 1 i.e. even to odd Contradicting corollary 1 . Hence the puzzle is unsolvable in this case as well.

It may have been nicer to restate lemma 4 as: for any move, the parity of the state stays the same (so if it is odd before it is odd after, and if it is even before it is even after), cause now the theorem simply says that the first configuration (with H G) which has parity 1 and the second which has parity 0 cannot ever be changed into each other though any set of moved. Lemma 4 now finishes the proof because the first has odd and the second even stated.

I've always had an issue with the name "Strong" induction. In maths, the more assumptions we make, the less powerful the theorem. So if we are assuming more for our induction hypothesis, I think the method should rather be called weak induction. Just a thought.

@sagar-tt4ub  its probably too late now and you might have already found the answer but i'll put this here anyways:  the relative position of a letter 'a' with respect to 'b' means that a is either before b or after b. anything else (ie. how many spaces, exactly, are between a and b) doesnt matter. what you're talking about (whether it's adjacent or not) is called absolute position, and it's a different thing.  when you move g over, its absolute position changes because there is now one space between g and d, whereas before they were adjacent. but its relative position remains the same because g is still after d.

Alex Armstrong Im probably late here, but for anyone else having the same question, p(n+1) is basically p(n) with the n replaced by n+1. In this case, the numerator of s(n) was n(n-1). So s(n+1) is going to be n+1(n+1-1) which is n(n+1).

@Celicaw8  because you want the sum from 1 to n -1, (the formula for the sum from 1 to n is n(n+1)/2) then you just change n to n-1, so the formula will be (n-1)(n-1+1)/2 that ends up as n(n-1)/2

1:01:00 Proving that 0 has P in Strong Induction is redundant.  In so called Well-Founded Induction you just prove that if all naturals less than n have P, then n has P, and infer that all naturals have P. The conditional is vacuously true for 0.
